content: The Act may be cited as the "Expanding Nutrition's Role in Curricula and Healthcare Act" or the "ENRICH Act". In 2012, US health care spending was $8,915 per resident, accounting for 17.2% of GDP. Expenditures surpassed $2.3 trillion in 2008, with chronic disease treatment costs making up over 75% of national health expenditures. The World Health Organization linked diet to chronic diseases, which cause 7 out of 10 American deaths annually. Heart disease, cancer, and stroke are major causes of death, accounting for over 50% of all deaths each year. Approximately 81.1 million Americans have cardiovascular disease, with 2,300 deaths daily. In 2010, cardiovascular disease cost $189.4 billion, projected to triple to $818 billion by 2030. Following a healthy diet can reduce heart disease symptoms and reverse artery damage. Two-thirds of Americans are overweight, with one-third of children being obese. In 2008, the United States spent $190 billion on obesity-related health care costs. An estimated 25.8 million Americans have diabetes, with another 79 million adults having prediabetes. Cancer kills approximately 570,000 Americans each year, with more than 1.5 million new cancer cases diagnosed annually. The direct costs of cancer were $102.8 billion in 2010, expected to rise to $172 billion by 2020. Over 33% of cancers are diet-related and preventable with a healthy diet. Nutrition education for clinicians can help identify effective strategies for counseling. Physician counseling on weight loss has been shown to increase patient motivation. Physician counseling on weight loss is recommended by leading medical bodies like the National Institutes of Health, American Heart Association, American College of Cardiology, and Obesity Society to help overweight and obese patients with lifestyle changes such as diet and physical activity. SEC. 3. Grants program for integrated nutrition curricula in medical schools. The Secretary of Health and Human Services will establish a grants program for medical schools in the US to develop integrated nutrition and physical activity curriculum. Grant funds must be used for creating or expanding such curriculum. The curriculum for the grants program for medical schools in the US will focus on improving communication and provider preparedness in preventing, managing, and reversing obesity, cardiovascular disease, diabetes, and cancer. It will also cover topics such as nutrition across the life cycle, physical activity training, food insecurity, and malnutrition among at-risk populations. Eligible entities must be medical schools in the United States to receive a grant. The grants program for medical schools in the US focuses on implementing an integrated nutrition and physical activity curriculum. Eligible schools must be accredited by specific organizations and submit an application detailing their curriculum implementation plans and success benchmarks. The grant awarded to a medical school is for a three-year period and cannot exceed $500,000. Each school is limited to one grant and priority is given to those with integrated nutrition and physical activity curriculum plans. The grant awarded to a medical school is for a three-year period and cannot exceed $500,000. Priority is given to schools with integrated nutrition and physical activity curriculum plans. The grant program requires coordination with a residency program or providing at least 25 hours of nutrition education to students. Partnering with education programs for physicians and non-physician health professionals is also encouraged. Reports on the grants program must be submitted to Congress annually. The report on the grants program includes findings on integrating nutrition and physical activity curriculum into medical schools, assessing benefits for providers and increasing awareness among physicians and health professionals. The Secretary will submit a final report to Congress within 180 days after the grants program ends, detailing recommendations on integrating nutrition and physical activity curriculum in medical schools and residencies. The report aims to address benefits and barriers of this integration. No additional funds are authorized for the requirements of this section. The Secretary will use up to $5,000,000 for each fiscal year from existing amounts for the grants program.
